data.title: Error: The workspace can only contain one instance of item [object Object]
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When working with multiple panes, Atom throws
 this error when trying to open non-editor tabs that are already open:

```
item-registry.coffee:8 Uncaught (in promise) Error: The workspace can only contain one instance of item [object Object](‚Ä¶)
module.exports.ItemRegistry.addItem @ item-registry.coffee:8
module.exports.PaneContainer.addedPaneItem @ pane-container.coffee:241
(anonymous function) @ pane-container.coffee:235
module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch @ emitter.js:25
module.exports.Emitter.emit @ emitter.js:129
module.exports.Pane.addItem @ pane.coffee:455
module.exports.Pane.activateItem @ pane.coffee:410
(anonymous function) @ workspace.coffee:525
```

Also, the result looks glitchy:

![screen shot 2017-01-20 at 12 30 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1504938/22148056/4721f7f8-df0c-11e6-8f2e-421cec4b3f01.png)

Take note, that both Settings panes have focus. The left pane has the correct title (‚ÄúSettings‚Äù), but the view remains empty. The right pane is *untitled* and shows the Settings view.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch new Atom window
2. Split Pane (for this example I used *Split Right*)
3. Select the left pane, then open Preferences
4. Select the right pane, then open Preferences again

**Expected behavior:** Either show the settings pane in both tabs or focus to the first opened pane.

**Actual behavior:** Throws error and produces visual glitch

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm --version 
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.5
git 1.9.5
```

### Additional Information

Tested in both, normal and safe mode, on Mac OS X 10.9.5

data.title: Add showCursorOnSelection config
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Adds a new config `editor.showCursorOnSelection`, enabled by default (changing the current default behavior), that makes it so that the cursor is always blinking even when you have a selection(s).

### Why Should This Be In Core?

It's pretty tied to the internals of `Cursor` and `TextEditor`.

### Benefits

Brings Atom in line with the behavior of Sublime (and others).

This is super useful for when you do `cmd+d` (`find-and-replace:select-next`) and you can't find where your cursor went.

### Possible Drawbacks

The current behavior is to hide the cursor when there's a selection. Since we're changing the default, that's sure to upset someone. However, since it is configurable, those that don't like it can easily revert to the old behavior.

data.title: 1.13 Regression: Font Family setting causing CssSyntaxErrors
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Note: I am only able to reproduce some of the issues.

### Description

Starting with the release of Atom 1.13.0, we have received [a](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-wont-start-up/38354) [number](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-1-13-update-non-functional/38189/10) [of](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13586) [bug](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/900) [reports](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13631) about the Font Family setting causing a `CssSyntaxError` to be thrown.  These errors did not appear in versions prior to 1.13.0, and while they may be correct, should at the very least be displayed in a more "pleasing" manner.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enter a quote or some otherwise malformed CSS into the Font Family box.  Some reports also suggest that a semicolon can cause the error, but I couldn't reproduce it.

**Expected behavior:** Nothing

**Actual behavior:** CssSyntaxError

**Reproduces how often:** 100% for quotes or otherwise invalid CSS, 0% for semicolons

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Not relevant, this is a 1.13 regression.  Appears to happen on all OSes.

data.title: Allow a BufferedProcess to be manually started
data.body: This is required so that settings-view can successfully set the proxy servers for apm - it's an async call that can't stop returning the bufferedProcess object to callers.

data.title: Fix broken link for macOS.
data.body:
### Requirements

This just fixes a broken link in README.md

### Description of the Change

Modify the link from `docs/build-instructions/macos.md` to `docs/build-instructions/macOS.md`, since the file has been renamed in 1cfcec2b72fa749285a5e67e7fc2ad9b04f7c15b

### Alternate Designs

No design change

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Documentation purposes

data.title: TextEditor's scrollPastEnd gets ignored
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The `scrollPastEnd` option for a `TextEditor` is not respected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install `git-diff-details` which makes use of this feature
2. Open a repo, create a diff that spans at least 5 lines
3. Place the cursor above the red area and scroll

**Expected behavior:**
Inline editor view does not scroll.

**Actual behavior:**
Inline editor view scrolls.

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions

1.14 Beta and lower

data.title: Atom corrupts open file on unplanned system shutdown.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom will corrupt the currently open and focused file when restarted after an unplanned poweroff.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file in Atom. (I usually open atom from a folder in command line like `~/project $ atom .`)
2. Make some changes.
3. Save them(?)
4. Pull out the power cord/hard-shutdown the computer üò±
5. Reboot, open Atom.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The file that was being edited appears undamaged, modulo any changes that may not have been flushed to disk.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Lovely lovely soup of random bytes everywhere, gleefully persisted to disk. Hope you were using Git so you can roll back to the latest commit/stash (you do commit often, right?).

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Every time I had to hard-reboot the computer while Atom was open.

### Versions

`atom --version`:

```
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

`apm --version`:

```
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12+
git 2.9.3
```

### Additional Information

Using Ubuntu 16.10 (`uname -a`: `Linux serenity 4.8.0-34-generic #36-Ubuntu SMP Wed Dec 21 17:24:18 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`)

I'll try to update this report as I gather more information.

data.title: Add option for closing deleted file tabs
data.body:
Adds a core option for keeping open editors whose underlying files are deleted outside Atom.

![screen shot 2017-01-18 at 4 40 27 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/553742/22088980/e1f25d3e-dd9c-11e6-81de-53846a511971.png)

To be merged in tandem with atom/text-buffer#178 (which will include tests for this option) and atom/tree-view#1026 in order to close atom/tabs#306.

Note that the default will change to keep these tabs open, as that's the conservative behavior with respect to potentially losing data.

data.title: Entire buffer cleared when file changes causing scroll position to be lost
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When using linters with auto-fix enabled (for example linter-eslint), it will fix code style errors for you upon saving the file you're working on, e.g. missing semi colon, incorrect indentation, etc.

For a while now, when this happens, Atom tends to momentarily blank out the window and then re-insert the fixed contents, causing the window to scroll up. This is problematic, as it causes you to lose your scroll position and as such your focus of the area of code you were working on.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install/enable only core packages and linter as well as linter-eslint
2. Use the following rules for eslint:

```
{
    "parser": "babel-eslint",
    "env": {
        "es6": true
    },
    "rules": {
        "semi": [ 1, "always" ]
    }
}
```

3. Open these file contents (thanks @dwelle) http://pastebin.com/raw/Yk6K1w5k and save as `test.js`.
4. Scroll to the bottom and remove the last semi colon.
5. Save the file

**Expected behavior:**
Contents remains visible, then is fixed/replaced by a fixed contents, while maintaining scroll position.

**Actual behavior:**
The buffer is cleared, then contents re-appears and the scroll position is at the top.

**Reproduces how often:**
Nearly 100% with the provided example file.

### Versions
OS X: 10.11.5
Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-157e8e1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.2

### Additional information
Note that while the example file is quite large with 3000+ lines, this behaviour *does* occur quite regularly with smaller files as well. It's just not 100% reproducible in those cases. But it could be that the file size/length emphasises the issue.

### See also
- https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/issues/620
- https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/issues/774
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11483

When I typed the file name and tried to press Enter nothing happened. But if I write text in any file the Enter key works perfectly. What is the problem?

data.title: Increase max listener limit on ipcRenderer
data.body:
We deliberately assign more than 10 listeners on the method response channel.

This should eliminate `Warning: Possible EventEmitter memory leak detected` spam when running tests.

/cc @BinaryMuse

data.title: Adopt Sublime Text's handling of punctuation at the start of alt-left/right
data.body:
### Description

Atom alt-left/right and alt-shift-left/right (skip over or select word) should ignore certain punctuation characters in front of the cursor. This makes it easier to select parts of a JavaScript property chain, for example.

### Steps to Reproduce

Tab through this text in Atom vs. Sublime Text:

    this.props.horse.cart.battery.staple

Tab through this text in Atom vs. Sublime Text:

    this.props.horse.cart['battery'][staple]

Screencast showing Sublime Text vs. Atom behaviour:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qovtU8MIygo&feature=youtu.be

**Expected behavior:**

In the first example when you start a selection before a period Sublime Text includes the period and continues to the next punctuation character. In the second example Sublime Text also skips over `['` at the beginning of the selection.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom stops at every punctuation character.

### Versions

Atom 1.13.0 x64 Mac

data.title: libXss.so.1 error on Fedora 25
data.body:
Hello,

There is an error with libXss.so.1 when trying to update to Atom 1.13 RPM on Fedora 25. 

When using --nodeps option, it works fine:

rpm -Uvh --nodeps atom.x86_64.rpm

Thanks

data.title: computer crash after  editing wxpython GUI code on the Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

### Description

when I had installed wxpython in my computer,I try to edit a example program to check whether wxpython is correct installation.

So,I input the example program:

```
import wx
app = wx.App()
win = wx.Frame(None)
win.Show()
app.Mainloop

``` 

But,when I input the second line code `app = wx.`,Atom should display the function in wxpython.But my computer crash directly.The mouse keyboard and screen can not response. I can only cut off the power supply to restore the computer.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. install wxpython
2. create file,and input the code
3. the computer is crash

**Expected behavior:** normally work

**Actual behavior:** computer crash

**Reproduces how often:** every time

data.title: Correct PUG-Filters incorrectly marked as syntax--invalid and syntax--illegal
data.body:

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

...

### Description

Correct PUG-Code with filters defined at [PUG filters](https://pugjs.org/language/filters.html) incorrectly marked as `.syntax--invalid` and `.syntax--illegal`

![2017-01-18 11 35 28](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4803370/22061094/c1171844-dd73-11e6-8f00-89e1a97c0075.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Type into any `.pug`-file:

```PUG
div
  :markdown-it(html typographer plugins=['markdown-it-sup', 'markdown-it-deflist', 'markdown-it-attrs'])
```

and see wrong syntax-highlighting.

### Versions

```bash
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]

$ atom --version

Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Window title is `untitled` when no files are open
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The title of the window is `untitled` even when there is no new/untitled file open.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project folder
2. Ensure all file tabs are closed

**Expected behavior:**
The title of the window should show the location of the project folder, so that when you are viewing the window and the tree view happens to be scrolled down (moving the root folder out of view) you will still know what window you're looking at.

Are present, if you have multiple windows open, they will all say `untitled` which isn't very helpful. I'm pretty sure this has been introduced in one of the latest releases and that it didn't use to be like this.

**Actual behavior:**
The title of the window says `untitled`

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions
Atom 1.14.0-dev-157e8e1
OS X 10.11.5

data.title: Check whether state store is connected when prompting to save files
data.body:
Because we rely on the state-store's availability to save unsaved changes in files it seems important to be able to check for the case where we never connected to the state store. This would be common for anybody who has multiple versions of Atom installed. Normal users probably don't do this often but as an Atom developer I certainly do. So this PR makes two changes:

1. Introduces an `isConnected` flag to `state-store`.

In the common (for me) case where you open e.g. beta after you've opened stable, and beta fails to connect to the indexedDB, it's set false.

2. Checks `atom.stateStore.isConnected` when determining whether to prompt to save file changes. Without this, changes are silently lost in this scenario.

Related to https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/306 and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13318.

/cc @nathansobo @as-cii for review

data.title: Atom opens multiple tabs for the same file on double-click
data.body:
Hello,

Apologies if this has already been asked, but I can't find any results for the problem I'm having.  Currently if I have a file open in a tab, then I double-click the same file in tree-view, it opens a new tab.  Is there an option to focus on the already open tab instead of opening a new one?

EDIT:  This seems to only happen when you have multiple panes open.
Steps to reproduce:
1. open several files
2. create a new pane with one of them
3. focus on a file in one of the panes
4. double click a file (from the tree-view) that is open in the opposite pane > this will open the same file in the pane you are focused on instead of focusing on the already open file's tab
 

Thank you,
Chris

data.title: Snippet not working
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I try to write a snippet for a TeX file.When I start to write`$in_R` the following snippet is not working:
```
'.text.tex.latex .string.other.math.tex':
    'in_R':
      'prefix': 'in_R'
      'body': "\\\\in \\\\mathbb{R}"
```

On the other hand, if I am not in math-mode in LaTeX everything works fine with this code:
```
'.text.tex.latex':
    'in_R':
      'prefix': 'in_R'
      'body': "\\\\in \\\\mathbb{R}"
```

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS is Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Reported potential regressions in v1.14-beta
data.body:
This is a tracking issue for things that the maintainers have vetted as potential regressions in v1.14-beta.

## Open

* [x] https://github.com/atom/markdown-preview/issues/462 - Uncaught TypeError: _this.css is not a function
* [x] https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13573 Install only the 64 bit version of libXss.so.1.
* [x] https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13647 Window title is `untitled` when no files are open
* [x] https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13738 Atom Beta 1.14 TextEditor.getPath() has inconsistent behavior with symlinks
## Fixed in 1.14.0-beta3

* [x] https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4619#issuecomment-273122379 - Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property slice of undefined (Can only reproduce with 1.14 or later using the steps in that comment)
* [x] https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/issues/841 - Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'slice' of undefined (find-and-replace package).  Fixed with https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/pull/844

data.title: keybinding use-selection-as-find-pattern
data.body:
In version 1.13.0-beta8.
If I want to find selected word first I need to push `Ctrl-f` and after that `Ctrl-e`.
Before it was done by pushing once `Ctrl-e`. Can you return this option?

data.title: Atom crashed when I add a certain directory into the project
data.body:
### Description

Everytime after I added one of my project by menu-> File -> Add project folder, Atom crashes.

### Versions

1.13.0 x64 on OS X El Capitan, Version 10.11.6
